race.name: OMG (Oxford MS Gravel)
race.tagline: Holly Springs National Forest gravel through rolling Mississippi hill country.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Mississippi hills. Moderate elevation with Southern scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional MS event. Hills terrain with small-medium local field.

biased_opinion.summary: OMG (Oxford MS Gravel) is a regional event in Mississippi—hills terrain with moderate elevation. The Southern scenery is pleasant, but the small-medium local field, regional organization, and limited prestige keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional MS gravel race. Worth it for MS/Southeast riders. Not worth traveling far for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to MS/Southeast—yes, it's solid. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Southeast races: Check regional options.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Oxford has lodging (college town). Book ahead.
logistics.food: Oxford has excellent dining. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Mississippi fall can still be hot and humid.
Mississippi hills require sustained rolling effort.

topics.heat: Riding in Mississippi heat and humidity

logistics.explanation: Part of the Mississippi Gravel Cup series organized by Matt Roland, Jason Shearer, and Landon Voller with confirmed 2025 date of January 11. The 2021 event managed COVID protocols with masked riders in waves of 50, but specific details on parking, packet pickup, and start logistics remain unclear.

length.explanation: Ben Gabardi won the 50-mile distance in 2:33:59.9, placing it in that awkward middle ground between morning spin and epic. The course offers 25 and 50-mile options with ride leaders for beginners, while the 100-mile distance conquers over 7,000 feet of climbing for those wanting a full day out. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: Holly Springs National Forest terrain features 'rolling hills, fun descents, gorgeous forest views and well-packed gravel service roads.' The course runs on service roads rather than gnarly singletrack, making it rideable but not technically demanding compared to rockier gravel events. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The 100-mile route gains over 7,000 feet through sustained rolling hills rather than major climbs. For the 50-mile distance, expect proportionally less elevation but still meaningful climbing through Mississippi's surprisingly hilly national forest terrain. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: January weather proved memorable in 2021 when Bart Luther noted 'Having snowflakes in Mississippi was a bonus!' Multiple team DNFs in 2024 suggest conditions can turn challenging quickly. January timing avoids summer humidity but brings winter weather uncertainty to the Deep South. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: This is Mississippi, not Colorado. You're riding at low elevation throughout the Holly Springs National Forest. Altitude won't factor into your performance or preparation strategy. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The 2021 race drew 'riders from all around Mississippi and even people from eight other states as far as Iowa and Colorado.' Holly Springs National Forest provides 'gorgeous forest views' through well-maintained gravel roads, offering scenic exploration without extreme technical challenges.

prestige.explanation: Opens the Mississippi Gravel Cup series with limited regional recognition. The 2021 field was capped at 160 riders due to COVID, and while the event draws some out-of-state participation, it remains largely invisible on the national gravel calendar.

race_quality.explanation: Organizers provided 'Premium swag, a sick finishers patch' even during COVID restrictions. Aid stations offer water, sports drink and snacks plus post-race meals. Jason Shearer noted riders 'signed up in minutes' when registration opened, indicating solid execution that keeps people coming back.

experience.explanation: Bart Luther observed 'Seeing all the smiles, seeing all the exhilaration, I think sometimes competition is good for the soul.' The event offers podium prizes three deep across multiple categories including Clydesdale/Athena, Sexagenarian, and Singlespeed divisions to accommodate different rider types.

community.explanation: Jason Shearer emphasized the series goal: 'We're really proud to bring people into our Mississippi communities and experience Mississippi on two wheels.' Even with COVID restrictions requiring masked volunteers and individually packaged snacks, the community atmosphere remained welcoming with 'fist bumps and socially distanced air hugs.'

field_depth.explanation: Scott Kuppersmith won the 100-mile elite division in 5:24:37.9 in 2025, showing some competitive depth. However, multiple Marx-Bensdorf/BPC Cycling Team riders DNF'd after strong first laps in 2024, suggesting the field lacks consistent national-level depth despite regional competition. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Entry fee isn't listed but Mississippi races typically run reasonable. 50 miles for probably under $75 beats getting gouged by the big-name events. Just don't expect much beyond basic course support for your money.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $65-85. Oxford is a college town with reasonable lodging options, and Mississippi generally keeps costs manageable. The January date likely helps with accommodation availability and pricing. No major airport means driving, but regional access keeps travel costs reasonable for most participants. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
